description: From brink (“border, edge”) +‎ -manship (suffix denoting expertise, involvement, or special status in an area).

entries.meaning: (chiefly politics) The pursuit of an advantage by appearing to be willing to take a matter to the brink (for example, by risking a dangerous policy) rather than to concede a point. [from mid 1950s]
examples: The diplomat accused the other nation’s leader of brinkmanship for refusing to redeploy the troops along their nations’ shared border.
